There are infinite numbers between 0 and 1. There's .1 and .12 and .112 and an infinite collection of others. Of course, there is a bigger infinite set of numbers between 0 and 2, or between 0 and a million. Some infinities are bigger than other infinities. This idea of different sizes of infinity was explored by the mathematician Georg Cantor. He showed that while the infinity of numbers between 0 and 1 is infinite, the infinity of real numbers as a whole is actually larger. This is known as different cardinalities of infinity. 

Even within the real numbers between 0 and 1, while the number of decimals is infinite, most of them are irrational numbers that can't be written out fully as decimals. Numbers like pi and the square root of 2 have decimal expansions that go on forever without repeating, even though they are still between 0 and 1. So infinity comes in many shades and sizes. It's a profound and counterintuitive aspect of mathematics that challenges our intuition about what it means for a set or process to keep going forever without end. Handling ideas of infinity requires new ways of conceptualizing sets and numbers.

I didn't plan on falling for her, but from the moment we met it was like I was helpless to stop it. Her smile made my heart race and I found myself hanging on her every word, no matter how mundane. I knew she didn't feel the same way. At least not yet. But I hoped that someday, somehow she might. Until then, I was helpless against the overwhelming force of an emotion I couldn't control and didn't want to lose. My heart had found its match and there was no going back.
